senses.sense: The unconscious impulsive component of the personality in the Freudian psychoanalytic model.
Alternative spelling of ide (the fish)
(computing) Identifier.
Used in citations to state that the citation is to the work immediately previously cited.
(biology, archaic) One of the nuclear rods or chromosomes in a fertilized ovum, supposed to contain an aggregate of the ids, or all kinds of biophores of the organism.
Alternative form of iddah
A freshwater fish of the family Cyprinidae, found across northern Europe and Asia, especially Leuciscus idus.
(philosophy) An abstract archetype of a given thing, compared to which real-life examples are seen as imperfect approximations; pure essence, as opposed to actual examples.
(obsolete) The conception of someone or something as representing a perfect example; an ideal.
(obsolete) The form or shape of something; a quintessential aspect or characteristic.
An image of an object that is formed in the mind or recalled by the memory.
examples: The mere idea of you is enough to excite me.

senses.sense: More generally, any result of mental activity; a thought, a notion; a way of thinking.
A conception in the mind of something to be done; a plan for doing something, an intention.
examples: I have an idea of how we might escape.

senses.sense: A purposeful aim or goal; intent
examples: Yeah, that's the idea.

senses.sense: A vague or fanciful notion; a feeling or hunch; an impression.
examples: He had the wild idea that if he leant forward a little, he might be able to touch the mountain-top.

senses.sense: (music) A musical theme or melodic subject.
Having a specified style or number of ideas.
Full of ideas.
Giving rise to ideas.
Optimal; being the best possibility.
Perfect, flawless, having no defects.
Pertaining to ideas, or to a given idea.
Existing only in the mind; conceptual, imaginary.
Teaching or relating to the doctrine of idealism.
examples: the ideal theory or philosophy

senses.sense: (mathematics) Not actually present, but considered as present when limits at infinity are included.
examples: ideal point
An ideal triangle in the hyperbolic disk is one bounded by three geodesics that meet precisely on the circle.

senses.sense: A perfect standard of beauty, intellect etc., or a standard of excellence to aim at.
examples: Ideals are like stars; you will not succeed in touching them with your hands. But like the seafaring man on the desert of waters, you choose them as your guides, and following them you will reach your destiny - Carl Schurz

senses.sense: (algebra, ring theory) A subring closed under multiplication by its containing ring.
examples: Let <math>\mathbb{Z}</math> be the ring of integers and let <math>2\mathbb{Z}</math> be its ideal of even integers. Then the quotient ring <math>\mathbb{Z} / 2\mathbb{Z}</math> is a Boolean ring.

The product of two ideals <math>\mathfrak{a}</math> and <math>\mathfrak{b}</math> is an ideal <math>\mathfrak{a b}</math> which is a subset of the intersection of <math>\mathfrak{a}</math> and <math>\mathfrak{b}</math>. This should help to understand why maximal ideals are prime ideals. Likewise, the union of <math>\mathfrak{a}</math> and <math>\mathfrak{b}</math> is a subset of <math>\mathfrak{a + b}</math>.

senses.sense: (algebra, order theory, lattice theory) A non-empty lower set (of a partially ordered set) which is closed under binary suprema (a.k.a. joins).
(set theory) A collection of sets, considered small or negligible, such that every subset of each member and the union of any two members are also members of the collection.
examples: Formally, an ideal <math>I</math> of a given set <math>X</math> is a nonempty subset of the powerset <math>\mathcal{P}(X)</math> such that: <math>(1)\ \emptyset \in I</math>, <math>(2)\ A \in I \and B \subseteq A\implies B\in I</math> and <math>(3)\ A,B \in I\implies A\cup B \in I</math>.

senses.sense: (algebra, Lie theory) A Lie subalgebra (subspace that is closed under the Lie bracket) ùñç of a given Lie algebra ùñå such that the Lie bracket [ùñå,ùñç] is a subset of ùñç.
(algebra) A subsemigroup with the property that if any semigroup element outside of it is added to any one of its members, the result must lie outside of it.
examples: The set of natural numbers with multiplication as the monoid operation (instead of addition) has multiplicative ideals, such as, for example, the set {1, 3, 9, 27, 81, ...}. If any member of it is multiplied by a number which is not a power of 3 then the result will not be a power of three.

senses.sense: Devoid of ideas.

Alternative spelling of idealized
simple past tense and past participle of idealise
Alternative form of idealizer

The property of a person of having high ideals that are usually unrealizable or at odds with practical life.
The practice or habit of giving or attributing ideal form or character to things; treatment of things in art or literature according to ideal standards or patterns;‚Äîopposed to realism.
(philosophy) An approach to philosophical enquiry, which asserts that direct and immediate knowledge can only be had of ideas or mental pictures.
plural of idealism
(philosophy) One who adheres to idealism.
Someone whose conduct stems from idealism rather than from practicality.
An unrealistic or impractical visionary.
Of or pertaining to an idealist or to idealism.

In an idealistic manner.
plural of idealist
plural of ideality
(uncountable) The quality or state of being ideal.
(uncountable) The capacity to form deals of beauty or perfection.
The conceptive faculty.
The act or process of idealizing.
The representation of natural objects, scenes, etc., in such a way as to show their most important characteristics; the study of the ideal.
plural of idealization
(transitive) To regard something as ideal.
(intransitive) To conceive or form an ideal.
(transitive, art) To portray using idealization.
(US) Regarded as ideal.
(US) Considered as an ideal form of something.
simple past tense and past participle of idealize
A person who idealizes.

third-person singular simple present indicative form of idealize
present participle of idealize
Devoid of ideals.
In an ideal way; perfectly.
Given ideal circumstances; preferably.
examples: Ideally, we would have one textbook per student, but unfortunately some of you will have to share.

senses.sense: The state or quality of being ideal; the ideality.
ideologic
Misspelling of ideologies.
One given to fanciful ideas or theories; someone who theorizes or speculates.
Someone who espouses a particular ideology, particularly a political one.

plural of ideal
A person who spreads or promotes ideas.
plural of idea
To apprehend in thought so as to fix and hold in the mind; to memorize.
To generate an idea.
Produced by an idea.

simple past tense and past participle of ideate
third-person singular simple present indicative form of ideate
present participle of ideate
The conceptualization of a mental image.
examples: suicidal ideation

senses.sense: (often business) The synthesis of ideas.
Pertaining to the formation of ideas or thoughts of objects not immediately present to the senses.
by means of, or in terms of, ideation
plural of ideation
Relating to ideation.
The same.
Idempotence.
(mathematics, computing) (said of a function) Such that, when performed multiple times on the same subject, it has no further effect on its subject after the first time it is performed.
examples: A projection operator is idempotent.

senses.sense: (mathematics) (said of an element of an algebraic structure with a binary operation, such as a group or semigroup) Such that, when it operates on itself, the result is equal to itself.
examples: Every finite semigroup has an idempotent element.
Every group has a unique idempotent element: namely, its identity element.

senses.sense: (mathematics) (said of a binary operation) Such that all of the distinct elements it can operate on are idempotent (in the sense given just above).
examples: Since the AND logical operator is commutative, associative, and idempotent, it distributes with respect to itself.

senses.sense: (mathematics) (said of an algebraic structure) Having an idempotent operation (in the sense given above).
(mathematics) An idempotent element.
(mathematics) An idempotent structure.
(Now chiefly dialectal, Northern England, Scotland) Diligent; persistent.
Identification.
(radio, television) A brief audio or audiovisual sequence serving to identify the broadcaster.
(Internet) A protocol serving to identify the user of a particular TCP connection, used especially on IRC networks.
Identifier.
(obsolete) Identical.

(diplomacy, obsolete) Precisely agreeing in sentiment or opinion and form or manner of expression; applied to concerted action or language used by two or more governments in treating with another government.
(not comparable) Bearing full likeness by having precisely the same set of characteristics; indistinguishable.
(not comparable) Not different or other; not another or others; not different as regards self; selfsame; numerically identical.
(not comparable, biology) Of twins, sharing the same genetic code.
(not comparable, mathematics) Exactly equivalent.
(comparable, rare) Approximating or approaching exact equivalence.
(usually pluralized, chiefly philosophy) Something which has exactly the same properties as something else.
An identical twin.
(poetry) A rhyme on the same syllable, such as "leave" and "believe".
The property of being identical.
In an identical manner.
examples: It was hard to tell the twins apart: they even spoke identically.

senses.sense: (math) In terms of an identity.
examples: two expressions that are identically equal to each other

senses.sense: The state or quality of being identical.
(uncountable) The quality of being identifiable.
Capable of being distinguished and named.
examples: I don't know where he was from because he had no identifiable accent.

senses.sense: The quality of being identifiable.
In a manner or state that is capable of being distinguished or named.
examples: The man was identifiably a tourist.
She maintained an identifiably Jewish home.

senses.sense: (strictly) The act of identifying (i.e., which one, which thing).
examples: In IP protocol, after identification comes authentication.

senses.sense: (broadly, often) The combination of identifying (which one, which thing) and validating the identity (proving or confirming it); identifying and authenticating viewed as a unitary concept in cognition.
examples: Much education and experience is required for proper identification of bird species.

senses.sense: The state of being identified.
examples: The problem's identification was the first step toward dealing with it.

senses.sense: (countable) A particular instance of identifying something.
examples: information necessary to make a good identification

senses.sense: A document or documents serving as evidence of a person's identity.
examples: The authorities asked for his identification.

senses.sense: A feeling of support, sympathy, understanding, or belonging towards somebody or something.
examples: identification with the tribe

senses.sense: Relating to identification.
plural of identification
simple past tense and past participle of identify
Someone who identifies; a person who establishes the identity of someone or something.
Something that identifies or uniquely points to something or someone else.
One who identifies as a particular type or role; one who says and believes that they are a certain thing.
A guidebook that helps determine the specific class of an object (such as a mushroom, herb, fish, bird, drug, or mineral), or its individual identity (such as that of a star).
(programming, operating systems) A formal name used in source code to refer to a variable, function, procedure, package, etc. or in an operating system to refer to a process, user, group, etc.
(HTML) A code that distinguishes a particular element from all other elements in a document.
(databases) A primary key.
plural of identifier
third-person singular simple present indicative form of identify
(transitive) To establish the identity of someone or something.
examples: It was hard to identify the shoplifter because the CCTV records didn't have a clear image.

senses.sense: (transitive) To disclose the identity of someone.
examples: The Associated Press will not identify the suspect of the crime because he is a juvenile.

senses.sense: (transitive, biology) To establish the taxonomic classification of an organism.
(transitive) To equate or make the same; to unite or combine into one.
(reflexive) To have a strong affinity with; to feel oneself to be modelled on or connected to.
(intransitive) To associate oneself with some group; to feel, or believe one feels, the same way.
(reflexive, with as) To claim an identity; to describe oneself as a member of a group; to assert the use of a particular term to describe oneself.
present participle of identify
An act of identification.
(philosophy) The doctrine that states of the mind and states of the brain are identical.
plural of identity
Sameness, identicalness; the quality or fact of (several specified things) being the same.

The difference or character that marks off an individual or collective from the rest of the same kind; selfhood; the sense of who something or someone or oneself is, or the recurring characteristics that enable the recognition of such an individual or group by others or themself.
examples: I've been through so many changes, I have no sense of identity.
This nation has a strong identity.

senses.sense: A name or persona‚Äîa mask or appearance one presents to the world‚Äîby which one is known.
examples: This criminal has taken on several identities.
In this show, the competitor's identity will remain secret until after the vote.

senses.sense: (mathematics) An equation which always holds true regardless of the choice of input variables.
examples: The equation (x+y)(x‚àíy) = x<sup>2</sup>‚àíy<sup>2</sup> is an algebraic identity. It is true regardless of the values of x and y.

senses.sense: (algebra, computing) Any function which maps all elements of its domain to themselves.
(algebra) An element of an algebraic structure which, when applied to another element under an operation in that structure, yields this second element.
(Australia, NZ) A well-known or famous person.
(philosophy) Originating ideas or images.
Synonym of ideogenic
(philosophy) The science dealing with the origin of ideas.
A symbol expressing an idea.
A picture or symbol which represents the idea of something without indicating the sequence of sounds used to pronounce it. Examples include digits, traffic signs, and graphic symbols such as @.
Alternative form of ideogrammic
Of or pertaining to ideograms.
Being, or pertaining to, an ideogram.
plural of ideogram
An ideogram.
Pertaining to an ideograph or ideography.

In an ideographic way
plural of ideograph
The use of ideograms; logography.

senses.sense: The worship, attachment, or devotion to a concept originating and existing in the mind as a result of mental understanding, awareness, or activity.
The worship or devotion to the thoughts and intents derived from the human mind.
The worship of the human intellect.
examples: The human mind can be easily deceived and convinced of its superiority and self-sufficiency, which is the core of Ideolatry.

Based on an ideology or misleading studies or statistics, especially based on the media or propaganda. Not based on scientific evidence or reality.

Doctrine, philosophy, body of beliefs or principles belonging to an individual or group.
examples: A dictatorship bans things, that do not conform to its ideology, to secure its reign.

senses.sense: (uncountable) The study of the origin and nature of ideas.
(physiology) An ideomotor movement.
Of or pertaining to involuntary actions caused by subconscious thought.
An inordinate fear of ideas, especially new ones, or of reasoning.
A word that utilizes sound symbolism to express aspects of events that can be experienced by the senses, like smell, color, shape, sound, action, or movement.

(physiology) Of or pertaining to a physiological process that is modified by mental activity.

A person who is compelled to carry out an idea.
A specimen identified as belonging to a specific taxon by the author of that taxon, but collected from somewhere other than the type locality

(historical, often capitalized) The notional full-moon day of a Roman month, occurring on the 15th day of the four original 31-day months (March, May, Quintilis or July, and October) and on the 13th day of all other months.
examples: The third day before the ides of March is March 13th; the third ides of August is August 11th; and the third of the ides of November is November 11th.

of, or relating to an idioblast

An act lacking intelligence or sense; an instance of senselessness; extremely foolish behaviour.
examples: The administrators, growing tired of such idiocy, put a new policy in place.

A manner of speaking, a mode of expression peculiar to a language, language family, or group of people.
examples: In English, idiom requires the indefinite article in a phrase such as "she's an engineer", whereas in Spanish, idiom forbids it.
Some of the usage prescriptions improved clarity and were kept; others that yielded discordant violations of idiom were eventually revised.

senses.sense: (programming) A programming construct or phraseology that is characteristic of the language.
A language or language variety; specifically, a restricted dialect used in a given historical period, context etc.
examples: In the idiom of the day, they were sutlers, although today they'd probably be called vendors.

senses.sense: An established phrasal expression whose meaning may not be deducible from the literal meanings of its component words.
examples: She often spoke in idioms, pining for salad days and complaining about pots calling the kettle black.

senses.sense: An artistic style (for example, in art, architecture, or music); an instance of such a style.
examples: the idiom of the expressionists

senses.sense: Pertaining or conforming to idiom, the natural mode of expression of a language.
examples: The inclusion or omission of definite articles follows idiomatic norms in each language and depends on context and intent.

In English, the only idiomatic position for a pronoun as the object of a phrasal verb is before the particle, whereas a noun as object can fall either before or after the particle; thus only he picked them up but either he picked his tools up or he picked up his tools.

senses.sense: Resembling or characteristic of an idiom.
examples: an idiomatic phrase that warns us against Pollyannaism is "don't count your chickens before they hatch".

senses.sense: (music) Relating to parts or pieces which are written both within the natural physical limitations of the instrument and human body and, less so or less often, the styles of playing used on specific instruments.

Idiomatic.
In an idiomatic manner.
With regard to idiomaticness; as analyzed with idiomatic meaning taken into account.

(linguistics, countable, rare) The state of a linguistic expression which exists when the expression exhibits semantic-pragmatic divergence, when the semantic value of the expression differs from its pragmatic value; that is to say, idiomaticity exists when the inherent meaning of the words expressed does not match the meaning of the expression as understood by the users: the sayer(s) and hearer(s).
(rare) Synonym of idiomaticity

(math) Belonging to the set of positive integers that cannot be expressed as ab + bc + ac for distinct positive integers a, b, and c.
The state or quality of being idoneous.
appropriate; suitable
The quality of being idoneous.
(biology, archaic) A plastid or unicellular organism, theoretically capable of development into a metazoan.
(carbohydrate) A sugar C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>12</sub>O<sub>6</sub> epimeric with gulose and obtainable along with gulose by synthesis from xylose.
A mineral wax obtained by distillation of idrialite.
(mineral) Synonym of idrialite
(mineral) A soft, orthorhombic hydrocarbon mineral, usually greenish-yellow to light brown in colour with bluish fluorescence.

Any poem or short written piece composed in the style of Theocritus's short pastoral poems, the Idylls.
An episode or series of events or circumstances of pastoral or rural simplicity, fit for an idyll; a carefree or lighthearted experience.
(music) A composition, usually instrumental, of a pastoral or sentimental character, e.g. Siegfried Idyll by Richard Wagner.
idyllic
Of or pertaining to idylls.
Extremely happy, peaceful, or picturesque.
An idyllic state or situation. (A substantive use of the adjective)

A writer of idylls; an idyllic poet or writer; one who depicts idyllic or pastoral subjects.
